comments.body: Other way around? `a.view(dtype=None, type=None)`.  Are the parenthesis needed?

No, it's right. This is actually a _type_ view (`np.void.view`) , not an _ndarray_ view (`np.ndarray.view`). The argument is a dtype format in tuple form `(base_type, descr)`  (ie, it would go in the `dtype=` argument of `np.ndarray.view`).

As an aside, `np.void.view` only accepts a single unnamed argument, while `np.ndarray.view` has named `dtype` and `type` arguments. Yet the dosctring for `np.void.view` says

> Not implemented (virtual attribute)
> Class generic exists solely to derive numpy scalars from, and possesses,
> albeit unimplemented, all the attributes of the ndarray class
> so as to provide a uniform API.

I am not sure what is going on there. It _is_ implemented, and it has a different method signature from `ndarray.view`.

Oh, and to clarify what this line does: It makes nested types behave like records too.

Demostration:

```
>>> rec = np.rec.array([('abc ', (1,1), 1), ('abc', (2,3), 1)],
... dtype=[('foo', 'S4'), ('bar', [('A', int), ('B', int)]), ('baz', int)])
```

Old behavior:

```
>>> rec[0].bar.A
AttributeError: 'numpy.void' object has no attribute 'A'
```

New behavior:

```
>>> rec[0].bar.A
1
```
Should we be checking here that the remainder is 0 too?

comments.body: Thinking again, I think this might fix a bug. Can you add a test that calls `fromarrays([some_int_array, some_structured_array])` and see if it behaves as you expect before and after this patch?

@eric-wieser 

```python
import numpy as np

x = np.arange(10)

y = np.ones(10, dtype=[('a', '<u2'), ('b', '<i4')])

y['a'] = np.arange(10, 20, dtype='<u2')
y['b'] = np.arange(-10, -20, -1, dtype='<i4')

z = np.core.records.fromarrays([x, y])

print(z)
```

with the patch the snippet works (as I expected)

```
[(0, (10, -10)) (1, (11, -11)) (2, (12, -12)) (3, (13, -13))
 (4, (14, -14)) (5, (15, -15)) (6, (16, -16)) (7, (17, -17))
 (8, (18, -18)) (9, (19, -19))]
```

comments.body: If it turns out that `isfileobj` can't be changed (see [this discussion](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/16675#discussion_r446736269)), then I suppose replacing these checks is fine. In that case it might be worth adding a comment to explain why `hasattr` is used and which types of objects match this condition.

Fixed (added a comment explaining)

Although I do think that we can aim for consistency between this method and `isfileobj`, that is either:
- both of them should be their own functions (Ex. `isfileobj` and `isfilelikeobj`, can try to come up with a better name for the new one as mentioned [here](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/16675#discussion_r446292087)) that way the tests will document which type of objects match. 
- Or both of them should be used directly at the position of the caller, since anyways `isfileobj` is not widely used (it is only used in `lib/format.py`)

What do you think?

TBH I'm not sure what the right move is. Here are some thoughts I have:
 - I'm against adding *more* `is*obj` functions to `numpy.compat` as I think it has the potential to cause a lot more confusion in the future, especially in the case of `isfileobj` and `isfilelikeobj` (imagine revisiting numpy.compat in the future without any of this discussion as context and trying to figure out why there are these two separate but very similar functions).
 - If `isfileobj` is only used internally in `lib.format`, then maybe removing the instances from the codebase is worthwhile, especially since the function itself is a one-liner. Based on the module docstring for `numpy.compat.py3k`, it seems that these functions were originally intended to bridge the gap between Python 2 and Python 3. Since we no longer support Python 2, it's possible that the `isfileobj` use in `lib.format` is no longer necessary. I'm not very familiar with the differences between Python 2/3 w.r.t. file handling. Maybe you (or someone else) have some insight here?
 - Expanding on the previous point - if it turns out that `isfileobj` is really only useful in the context of Python 2/3 compatibility (and not Python 3.X/3.Y compatiblity), then maybe it would nice to remove it's use internally and deprecate it?

Doing a grep on the entire repo I can say that `isfileobj` is only used in `lib.format`. However even I am not aware about the differences of file handling b/w Python 2/3. So I don't know if the impl. of `isfileobj` can be simplified further, since Python 2 is no longer supported.

Also, my thought of being consistent between `isfileobj` and this new one liner was a mere suggestion. Incase we dont get any feedback from more well-versed people about `isfileobj` in a few days, then can we still go ahead and finalize this PR as it is?
@rossbar the isfileobj deprecation can be moved into separate issue (not sure about it either)? I think we can move forward with this PR as is.

Yes, thanks for the ping @anirudh2290  - I agree that it shouldn't be a blocker. My vote would be to move forward with this PR avoiding functions from `numpy.compat`. I will try to take another look soon.
